title: INLAND WEATHER: October weather so hot, it’s scary
text:
STAFF REPORTS
Published: Oct. 9, 2015 Updated: Oct. 10, 2015 4:02 p.m. Inland temperatures were inching toward the century mark Saturday afternoon.
At 3 p.m., highs around the region included 100 in Corona, 98 in Corona, 97 in Riverside, 96 in Temecula and 95 in Moreno Valley.
The heat wave is expected to ease up a wee bit on Sunday, ushering in a few days of sunshine and humidity of around 20 percent.
Later in the week, possibly around Wednesday, a low-pressure trough is expected to bring slight cooling and possibly showers, according to National Weather Service forecasts.
That rain, if it materializes, would ease the danger of wind-whipped fires, but local fire officials remain on high alert due to the unseasonably high temperatures the region has experienced in recent days.
“We continue to have our staffing boosted up throughout the season because of the weather,” Cal Fire spokeswoman Jennifer Fuhrman said Friday. “Everything’s covered.”
The fire season typically runs through October.
Riverside, which sweltered at 104 degrees Friday, is expected to top out at 99 degrees today, said Mark Moede, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service.
A high-pressure system over Central California, coupled with a mild Santa Ana weather pattern, will keep temperatures unseasonably warm until the end of next week, Moede said.
“Hot. That’s the key word,” Moede said.
Although no records have been broken, temperatures on Friday were about 20 degrees higher than is normal for this time of year.
Weak Santa Ana winds were reported in the Banning area, with gusts up to 30 mph.
The combination of Santa Ana winds and high temperatures has proven deadly in the past, especially in October 2007 when fires that broke out up and down the Interstate 15 corridor caused millions of dollars in damage.
Moede said temperatures are expected to drop about another 5 degrees Sunday but said a significant cooling trend is not expected until Thursday or Friday.
Riverside and San Bernardino counties issued heat advisories for the weekend.
“While this magnitude of heat is not especially unusual, the recent cool weather could cause some people to be caught off-guard, especially those most susceptible to heat illness,” San Bernardino County Health Officer Dr. Maxwell Ohikhuare said.
Health officials warned that the elderly, infants and children, people who work or exercise outside and people with chronic medical conditions should take precautions in the extreme heat to keep from getting heat exhaustion or heat stroke.
Inland residents are advised to reschedule strenuous activities to the early morning or evening, wear lightweight and loose-fitting clothing and drink plenty of water.
Anthony Coletta, emergency services manager for the Riverside Fire Department, said the city has not added extra staffing for the weekend but has additional fire crews on call for emergencies.
“Our procedures allow us to recall additional personnel when we need to,” Coletta said.
Coletta said city cool centers, which are located in libraries, senior centers and community centers, would be open during normal business hours.
